thread.title: These 55 Patriots players caught Tom Brady’s first 400 touchdown passes - Patriots
thread.title_full: These 55 Patriots players caught Tom Brady’s first 400 touchdown passes - Patriots

author: boston.com
title: These 55 Patriots players caught Tom Brady’s first 400 touchdown passes - Patriots
text:
Membership in the NFL’s 400 touchdown club is exclusive.
It has been a bit easier to earn a spot in Tom Brady’s touchdown club.
The New England Patriots’ quarterback threw his first career touchdown pass to wide receiver Terry Glenn on Oct. 14, 2001. More than 4,000 completions later, he tossed his 400th career touchdown pass to wide receiver Danny Amendola on Sept. 27, 2015. In between, Brady threw touchdowns to a Brady (no relation), a Jackson, two Johnsons, a Tim Wright, a Tim Dwight, and a linebacker.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Here are the 55 players to catch at least one of Tom Brady’s first 400 career touchdown passes.
Rob Gronkowski (57 touchdown catches)
Randy Moss (39)
Wes Welker (34)
Deion Branch (24)
Aaron Hernandez (18)
Daniel Graham (17)
Ben Watson (17)
Julian Edelman (16)
David Patten (16)
Troy Brown (15)
Christian Fauria (13)
David Givens (12)
Kevin Faulk (10)
Mike Vrabel (8)
Shane Vereen (7)
Brandon LaFell (7)
Tim Wright (6)
Jabar Gaffney (6)
Danny Amendola (4)
Aaron Dobson (4)
Danny Woodhead (4)
Reche Caldwell (4)
Brandon Lloyd (4)
Bethel Johnson (4)
Donte’ Stallworth (4)
Kenbrell Thompkins (4)
Antowain Smith (3)
Chad Jackson (3)
Doug Gabriel (3)
Jermaine Wiggins (3)
Corey Dillon (2)
Marc Edwards (2)
Alge Crumpler (2)
Sam Aiken (2)
Donald Hayes (2)
Brandon Tate (2)
Tim Dwight (2)
Kyle Brady (2)
Chris Baker (2)
Charles Johnson (1)
Terry Glenn (1)
Laurence Maroney (1)
Heath Evans (1)
Andre’ Davis (1)
Scott Chandler (1)
Matthew Mulligan (1)
Larry Centers (1)
Dedric Ward (1)
Cam Cleeland (1)
Brian Tyms (1)
Patrick Pass (1)
Michael Hoomanawanui (1)
Chad Johnson (1)
Tom Ashworth (1)
David Thomas (1)
*All stats via Pro-Football-Reference.com
Tom Brady Career Timeline
Previous -- of -- Next In 29 college games with the Michigan Wolverines, Brady completed 61.9 percent of his passes for 4,773 yards with 30 touchdowns and 17 interceptions. AP/John L. White Previous -- of -- Next Brady had a very unspectacular NFL combine, failing to impress NFL scouts in athletic testing drills. NFL Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots drafted Brady with the 199th pick in the sixth round of the 1999 NFL Draft. He spent his rookie season backing up Drew Bledsoe at quarterback. Bill Greene/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Bledsoe suffered a sheared blood vessel in his chest after a brutal hit against the Jets in Week 2 of the 2001 season. Brady became QB1 for the Patriots. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next After Brady started the next eight games, Patriots coach Bill Belichick opted to stick with the kid even when Bledsoe was cleared to return. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Brady ran for a touchdown — in the snow — in his first playoff game, the AFC divisional round game vs. the Raiders. It was the final game in the old Foxboro Stadium. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next On one of the most controversial plays in NFL history, Brady’s fumble against the Raiders is overturned on the “Tuck Rule,” preserving the Patriots’ season. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady sustained a leg injury in the AFC Championship game at Pittsburgh, but Bledsoe came off the bench to lead the Patriots to the Super Bowl. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady threw a touchdown pass to David Patten on this play in Super Bowl XXXVI. Brady was named MVP as the Patriots defeated the Rams, 20-17. Bill Greene/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady is in disbelief following the Patriots upset victory over the Rams in Super Bowl XXXVI. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Following the Patriots’ Super Bowl victory over the Rams, Brady went to Disney World. AP/Peter Cosgrove Previous -- of -- Next Brady made the Pro Bowl in his first season as a starting quarterback. Through the 2014 season, he’s made 10 Pro Bowls. AP/Reed Saxon Previous -- of -- Next Bledsoe was traded to the division rival Bills in 2002. The Patriots won five out of six games against the Bledsoe-led Bills teams from 2002 through 2004. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots went just 9-7 and missed the playoffs in 2002, Brady’s first full season as the starter. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots returned to the playoffs in 2003 with a league-best 14-2 record. Here, Brady connects on a deep touchdown to Bethel Johnson in a 17-14 win over the Titans in the divisional round. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Brady outdueled Peyton Manning in the 2003 AFC Championship game at Gillette, and the Patriots beat the Colts 24-14. Stan Grossfeld, Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady throws a touchdown pass to linebacker/redzone tight end Mike Vrabel in Super Bowl XXXVIII. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady celebrates Adam Vinatieri’s game-winning field goal to beat the Panthers in Super Bowl XXXVIII. Stan Grossfeld, Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady dated movie star Bridget Moynahan for three years between 2004 and 2006. The couple had a child together in 2007. AP/Chris Pizzello Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Patriots made three trips to the White House during George W. Bush’s time in office. AP/Ron Edmonds Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots traded for running back Corey Dillon in 2004. He ran for a franchise-record 1,635 yards in 2004 and gave Brady the most productive backfield mate of his career. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots set an NFL record with 21 consecutive victories between 2003 and 2004, but the streak was snapped by the Pittsburgh Steelers in Week 8 of the 2004 season. John Bohn/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady topped Manning again in the AFC divisional round, as the Patriots bested the Colts 20-3. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Pats enacted revenge over Pittsburgh with a 41-27 victory in the AFC Championship game. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady connected with Vrabel for a second Super Bowl touchdown in as many years. The Patriots beat the Philadelphia Eagles 24-21 and cemented themselves as a dynasty with a third championship in four years. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Brady hoists his third Lombardi Trophy. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Patriots paraded through Boston following the team’s third Super Bowl in four seasons. A decade would pass before they would do it again. Stan Grossfeld/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady hosted Saturday Night Live in April of 2005. Yes, that’s Amy Poehler and Beck on stage with him. AP/Dana Edelson Previous -- of -- Next Ben Watson caught this touchdown pass from Brady, and the Patriots rolled past the Jacksonville Jaguars in the 2005 wild card round. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady’s 10-0 postseason record went up in flames in the divisional round in Denver. The Broncos beat the Patriots 27-13. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots trounced the Jets 37-16 in the wild card round of the 2006 playoffs. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady threw an interception late against the Chargers in the divisional round, but Troy Brown’s strip kept the season alive and Brady finished the comeback win. Jim Davis/Boston globe Previous -- of -- Next But a stunning comeback by Manning and the Colts knocked the Patriots out of the 2006 AFC Championship game. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady begins dating supermodel Gisele Bundchen in 2006. They are currently married with two children. Globe file photo Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots traded for star receiver Randy Moss in 2007, proving to ignite the offense and helped Brady take his game to new heights. Jim Rogash/Getty Images Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next This touchdown pass in week 17 set single-season records for passing (Brady, 50) and Moss (receiving, 23) scores in a season. The Patriots went 16-0 in the 2007 regular season, and Brady was voted league MVP. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next For the second straight year, Brady and the Patriots knocked the Jaguars out of the playoffs. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Pats moved to 18-0 with their AFC Championship game victory over the Chargers. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next TV reporter Ines Gomez Mont proposed to Brady at Super Bowl Media Day. Stan Grossfeld/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The New York Giants pulled off the biggest upset in Super Bowl history, ruining the Patriots’ perfect season with a 17-14 win. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Brady tears the ACL in his left knee in Week 1 of the 2008 season, ending his season. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady returned in 2009 and threw a pair of TD passes in a comeback win over the Bills in Week 1. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Patriots got smoked on their home field in the AFC wild card round in 2009, falling to the Ravens 33-14. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next In a sign of things to come, Brady hooks up with rookie tight end Rob Gronkoswi for three touchdowns in a Week 10 win over the Steelers. Brady was voted NFL MVP in 2010. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots throttled the Lions on Thanksgiving Day in 2010, and Brady got a tasty postgame snack for his efforts. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Patriots were upset on their home field by the rival New York Jets in the divisional round of the 2010 playoffs. Stan Grossfeld/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady hits Wes Welker for a 99-yard touchdown, matching the longest play from scrimmage in NFL history and leading the Patriots over the Miami Dolphins in Week 1 of the 2011 season. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady has connected on more passes with Welker than any other receiver in his career (632). Deion Branch is second with 384. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots knocked off the Ravens in the 2011 AFC Championship game, advancing to the fifth Super Bowl of Brady’s career. Stan Grossfeld/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Giants best Brady and the Patriots again in the Super Bowl, this time winning 21-17 after Brady’s “Hail Mary” goes unanswered on the final play. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots blew out the Jets on Thanksgiving night in 2012, and Brady celebrated with teammates Vince Wilfork and Steve Gregory after the game. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady connected with Shane Vereen on this touchdown pass in the Patriots’ 2012 divisional round win over the Houston Texans. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Ravens got revenge on Brady and New England in an AFC Championship rematch to end the Patriots’ 2012 season. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots overcame a 24-0 halftime deficit to beat the Broncos 34-31 in overtume in Week 12 of the 2013 season. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots dominated the Colts in the 2013 divisional round. Stan Grossfeld/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Broncos were too much for Brady and the Patriots in the 2013 AFC Championship Game, which Denver won 26-16. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady and the Patriots got off to a rough start to the 2014 season, which hit rock bottom when Brady was benched in a Week 4 loss to the Kansas City Chiefs. AP/Charlie Riedel Previous -- of -- Next In the five games following the loss to the Chiefs, Brady threw 18 touchdown passes and just one interception. The Patriots rebounded and finished 12-4 on the season. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady ran for a touchdown in a thrilling 35-31 win over the Ravens in the 2014 divisional round. Stan Grossfeld/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Another postseason beatdown of the Colts had Brady and the Patriots headed to their sixth Super Bowl in 14 years. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next In the wake of the AFC Championship game, reports surfaced that the NFL was investigating the Patriots for using underinflated footballs. The Deflategate scandal was born. John Tlumacki/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Julian Edelman caught this touchdown pass that ultimately proved to be the game winner in Super Bowl XLIX. The Pats topped the Seattle Seahawks 28-24. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next At long last, Brady had won his fourth Lombardi Trophy. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Brady gave his Super Bowl MVP truck to Malcolm Butler, a rookie cornerback who made the interception to clinch the game for the Patriots. AP/Josh Reynolds Previous -- of -- Next Brady threw out the first pitch on Opening Day at Fenway Park in 2015. Maddie Meyer/Getty Images Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next NFL investigator Ted Wells released a report on the Deflategate scandal, and determined Brady was “at least generally aware” of the Patriots “more probable than not” tampering with the footballs. Globe File Photo Previous -- of -- Next The NFL suspended Brady for four games for his role in Deflategate, and Commissioner Roger Goodell appointed himself to hear Brady’s appeal. AP/Charles Rex Arbogast Previous -- of -- Next On June 23, 2015, Brady’s team makes their case for exoneration during a 10-hour testimony in New York City. AP/David J. Phillip Previous -- of -- Next More than a month after the NFL heard Brady’s appeal, Goodell upheld the original four-game suspension handed down by the league. In its announcement, the NFL cited information about the destruction of Brady’s cell phone disclosed after the release of the Wells Report. Reuters/Lucy Nicholson Previous -- of -- Next Tom Brady’s team wins in federal court. After several weeks of failed negotiations between Brady and the NFL, U.S. District Court Judge Richard Berman ruled to nullify the New England Patriots quarterback’s four-game suspension.Platt/Getty Images) Spencer Platt Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement
